description: Unknown. Earliest recorded use in the phrase fair dinkum in 1879, from Australia. Also recorded (slightly later) from Derbyshire and Lincolnshire dialect. Perhaps related to Gloucestershire dialect ding (“to work hard”).

adjectives.description: dinkum (comparative more dinkum, superlative most dinkum)

entries.meaning: (Australia, New Zealand, slang) Genuine, true, honest, on the level. [From 1894]
examples: Larry's jeep was behind mine, and as I went past an intersection, I saw a lot of their chaps around a dinkum super Mark VI tank — p'raps a Mark VII or VIII. I didn't have a chance for a proper dinkum look-see, what?

entries.meaning: (Australia, New Zealand, slang, rare, obsolete) Hard work. [From 1882]
